measured_by: binary radio-button question: 'appears to be an intelligent person / unintelligent person'
justification: The Methods section states: “the intelligence question is first presented as two radio-buttons: The person in this image: • appears to be an intelligent person • appears to be an unintelligent person,” indicating this forced-choice item operationalises facial intelligence judgements.

measured_by: binary radio-button question: 'appears to be a trustworthy person / untrustworthy person'
justification: Immediately after the intelligence item the authors note: “the trustworthiness question is then presented: The person in this image: • appears to be a trustworthy person • appears to be an untrustworthy person,” showing trustworthiness is assessed with this specific forced-choice item.

measured_by: binary radio-button question: 'appears to be a dominant person / vulnerable person' (or dominance wording within co-measured options)
justification: In contexts where dominance is judged the protocol offers radio-button options such as “…appears to be a trustworthy, dominant person… appears to be an untrustworthy, dominant person,” evidencing that dominance perceptions are captured through binary dominance wording within the response set.
